properties.name: La Petite Maison
properties.description: Posted by Baobot 1015 W. Colorado Avenue, Colorado Springs, CO, United StatesSince 1978, La Petite Maison has charmed its dinner guests with some of the best French contemporary cuisine in Colorado Springs. Owner and Chef, Henri Chaperont, oversees every detail of the food served and makes it the reason you\'ll come back again and again. All of the dishes are prepared to order using carefully chosen fresh ingredients and herbs from their own gardens. The menu features savory flavors and tastes from a variety of cuisines and cultures, and includes meat, fresh fish, lamb, pork, duck and pasta dishes prepared in Hours: Lunch: Tues-Fri, 11:00 am - 2:00 pm Dinner: Tues-Sat, 5:00 - 10:00 pm Sunday 5:00 - 9:00 pm Closed on Mondays. Wine List: The wine list has been voted Best Restaurant Wine List in "Best of the Springs" by the Colorado Springs Independent, combining good value with a high quality selection. Private Dining: La Petite Maison can comfortably accommodate large groups. A private dining room can seat between 15 and 25 people. Smaller groups up to 10 can be seated at one table, or two or three tables can be arranged near each other for groups from 10 to 14. Our beautiful patio seats 48. Contact us by Email for Private Dining requests, or by phone at 719-632-4887. Patio Dining: Perfect during our warm Colorado days. Just the right amount of sunshine! Our comfortable patio can seat up to 48 people. Payment: American Express, Diners Club, Carte Blanche, Discover, MasterCard, VISA, and personal checks. the traditions of the classics with a contemporary flair. On any given night, Desserts may include Creme Brulee au Cardemon, Tarte Tatin with Creme Fraiche, Chocolate Pate with Lavender Creme Anglaise, Souffle (Grand Marnier, Chocolate, Berries) and Housemade Ice Cream and Sorbets. La Petite Maison is located in a restored Victorian cottage built in 1894 on the historic West Side of Colorado Springs. The restaurant opened for business in June of 1978, and has dedicated itself to the continuous quality and attention to detail that make it a truly great restaurant. While dining in one of the two dining rooms in this beautifully appointed cottage, you will enjoy the elegant air of the restaurant, as well as the quiet and friendly atmosphere of a home that will make you and your dinner companions feel as though you\'re the only guests. The servers are attentive and unobtrusive. "This is probably the best in Colorado Springs, as far as we\'ve found. Service is perfect. As near as we could see, there were only one or two waitstaff with busboys; but, the flow was incredible. We never knew our waitress by name, never asked for anything--it was just there. The presentation is as appealing as the taste.This is a must if in Colorado Springs and well worth the drive up from Denver. It is becoming more popular by the minute. Everyone I send loves it as much as I do!" Gabby Gourmet of the Denver Restaurant Guide The Zagat Survey of restaurants of the Rocky Mountain Region rated La Petite Maison in the top category of "extraordinary to perfection": "Most agree that this long-time Colorado Springs French restaurant is "totally charming" and "delightfully romantic"; "don\'t miss the wine list" say oenophiles; the service and quality of preparation are "consistently excellent"; in sum, "a terrific" experience.&q

properties.name: Lakewood Library
properties.description: Posted by Baobot 10200 West 20th Ave., Lakewood, COYou feel smarter just walking into the Lakewood Library. Here it seems as if you could find out anything you might possibly want to know. For example, team up with the reference librarians to answer tricky questions. Lakewood has the oldest and largest reference section in the Jefferson County Public Library, and the staff loves a challenge. Or track down that elusive ancestor. In addition to JCPL online and reference resources, Lakewood has the largest genealogy collection of all the JCPL libraries. (Check out the Foothills Genealogical Society Web page.) You can also catch up on the latest government and legal information. Lakewood is an official depository for United States, Colorado, Jefferson County, and City of Lakewood documents, and also has a collection of Colorado and U.S. statutes and cases. If your mood runs more to recreation, check out the large video collection, with movies for kids in the children\'s room. Browse through the magazines, the largest selection in JCPL. Join one of several book clubs for kids or adults. Meet the neighbors who have been coming to this library for 25 years. They know this is a comfortable place to work or relax. You\'re likely to ag

properties.name: Lannie's Clocktower Cabaret
properties.description: Posted by Baobot1601 Arapahoe St., Denver, CO, United StatesLannie\'s Clocktower Cabaret stretches luxuriously beneath one of Denver\'s most recognized icons: the historic Daniels and Fisher Tower. While the nightclub is new to the scene, the Clocktower has been standing watch over the heart of Denver for almost a hundred years. The first "skyscraper" in Denver\'s skyline, the D&F Tower was built in 1910, and measures 375 feet from street to the top of the flagpole. Modeled after Venice\'s famous Campanile in the Piazza San Marco, the Clocktower is an excellent example of the architectural style of the Italian Rennaissance. The Daniels and Fisher Dry Goods Store was part of the Tower when it was first built, and occupied all of 16th Street between Arapahoe and Lawrence. In addition to serving the needs of the bustling downtown community, the store kindly accommodated the hundreds of visitors who wanted to stare in awe at the "Purple Mountains Majesty" from the Tower\'s 21st Floor. Listed in the National, Colorado, and Denver Historic Registers, the D&F Tower is a timeless classic... and the perfect home for Lannie\'s. ---www.lannies.com

properties.name: Larimer Lounge
properties.description: Posted by Baobot2721 Larimer Street, Denver, CO, United StatesThe Larimer Lounge first started as a concept amongst a group of music loving friends attending the University of Colorado at Boulder in the early 90??s. It was obvious at the time that there was no one catch-all club attempting to bring in all the different elements of the burgeoning independent rock scene that was going on in the country at that point in time. One case in point ?? when a friend wrote a letter to the amazing northwest based band Seaweed saying they should come play Denver sometime, the letter writer later received a phone call from the bands agent asking for help trying to find a show in Denver. Seaweed eventually did come, and played a show at ?? eh em, The Church along with Spell (the band whose members would later form The Geds). After graduation, three guys from the circle of friends, Scott, Scott and Hans attempted to start their own club, but soon learned that their lack of experience was too large a barrier to facilitate the transition of making a venue from a dream into reality. One of these friends decided to book another club for years and was fortunate to have been part of many up and coming artists early shows in Denver, amongst them QUEENS OF THE STONE AGE, THE WHITE STRIPES, BRIGHT EYES, THE SHINS, AND YOU WILL KNOW US BY THE TRAIL OF DEAD, FLOGGING MOLLY, DEATH CAB FOR CUTIE, THE PROMISE RING, JIMMY EAT WORLD, THE RAPTURE and many more. In 2002 the pals finally got their own venue ?? The Larimer Lounge. They remain committed to providing a relaxed atmosphere where customers can have a good time while viewing live performances from the across the spectrum of independent rock that is currently going on in this country and around the wo

properties.name: Lucile's
properties.description: Posted by Baobot275 S. Logan St., Denver, CO, United StatesLucile\'s Restaurant was established in 1980, by myself and my mother, Lucile Richards. We developed a Creole menu shortly thereafter and shifted the restaurant\'s goals to becoming the nation\'s premier brunch restaurant. Lucile\'s first chef received his training from the famous New Orleans restaurant, "Commanders Palace." A breakfast and lunch restaurant serving a Creole theme had never been attempted before in Colorado. However, within a brief period, Lucile\'s had made its mark with such unique meals as "Cajun Breakfast" (red beans, poached eggs, hollandaise and grits) and "Eggs New Orleans" (fried eggplant, poached eggs, creole and hollandaise). Over the years, Chef Mickey Samuels has developed both the breakfast and lunch menus into culinary delights. He continues to enrich the daily selections by using only the freshest produce, meat and seafood available each day. It is under Chef Mickey\'s culinary direction that Lucile\' s has received the following prestigious awards: â¢ "FIVE STAR REVIEW" - The Boulder Daily Camera â¢ "BEST CREOLE RESTAURANT" - Westword Magazine â¢ "BEST BREAKFAST IN BOULDER" - The Boulder Daily Camers â¢ "BEST BREAKFAST/BRUNCH" - Boulder Weekly Magazine We have also been honored by having a song entitled "Breakfast at Lucile\'s," written and performed by our frequent customers, "The Little Women Band." Lucile\'s expanded by opening a second restaurant in January of 1996, located in Fort Collins, Colorado. The Fort Collins restaurant is run day to day by Tony Hanks, a born and bred Creole from Louisiana. Longmont Colorado came just one year after the Fort Collins location and the Steamboat Springs location was just recently opened in spring of 2003. The future for Lucile\'s is to open new locations across the United States using the same formulas that have worked so well in Boulder, Fort Collins, Longmont and Steamboat Springs. In addition, we have developed our own food products and signature items. We create and sell our own Creole seasonings; we use only Chef Mickey\'s homemade jam, we are well known for our private blend of "Lucile\'sCoffee" and we have established an excellent catering service. Lucile\'s has made a commitment to be at the forefront and cutting edge of breakfast and lunch cuisine, offering our high standards and consistent and efficient serv

properties.description: Posted by Baobot2027 Olde West Colfax Avenue, Denver, CO, United StatesHear Wendy Weber, national executive recruiting firm president, share her expertise with employees and employers about hiring, salaries, trends and how-tos in the direct marketing industry. Anyone involved in marketing or hiring will benefit by attending the presentation. The event is open to RMDMA members and non-members will be held at Mile High Station, 2027 Olde West Colfax Avenue in Denver, south of Mile High Stadium at Invesco Field and under the Colfax Avenue bridge. You will learn: *What to pay based on title, job description, responsibilities and location *What interview techniques employers should use and what to avoid *How job candidates can avoid the three biggest career mistakes *How to position your skills on your resume and how long it should be *When you should leave your job and when you should stay Interviewing dos and donâts Plus a free bonus to all attendees! Every attendee will receive a copy of the Annual Salary Guide listing dozens of positions in Direct Marketing. This valuable tool for employees and employers sells for 5.00. Weber is President of Crandall Associates, Inc, a national executive recruiting firm specializing in direct marketing since 1973. She is a frequent industry writer and committed industry participant. Crandall Associates is recognized throughout Direct Marketing as a pioneer, innovator and authority in conducting and completing executive searches in the industry, and was the first executive recruitment firm to recognize the emergence of direct marketing as a major marketing channel. Direct Marketing Jobs, Salaries and Hiring Practices: How Employers and Employees Can Live Happily Ever Afterâ, March 7th luncheon presentation, 12:00 â 1:15 p.m. Luncheon: RMDMA Member: 0 Non-members: 5 For more information visit the RMDMA website at www.rmdma.org or telephone Mary Shaw, Executive Director at 303.914.8

properties.name: Museum of Contemporary Art Denver
properties.description: Posted by Baobot  1275 19th St., Denver, CO, United StatesThe MUSEUM OF CONTEMPORARY ART | DENVER (MCA) is an innovative forum that inspires and challenges all audiences and creates understanding and dialogue about art of our time. MCA was founded in 1996 by a group of energetic community volunteers and artists deeply committed to creating a permanent home for contemporary art in Denver. Over its brief ten-year history MCA has grown into a vibrant organization that delivers contemporary art to the broader community, serving audiences ranging from artists, families, and scholars to those unfamiliar with contemporary art.

properties.name: Museum of Contemporary Art, Fort Collins
properties.description: Posted by Baobot  201 S. College Ave., Fort Collins, CO, United StatesThe mission of the Fort Collins Museum of Contemporary Art is to engage our community in cultural experiences that promote the creation and appreciation of contemporary art. Contemporary art is the art of our time, including living artists and those from the past whose work informs the present. To exemplify the best in contemporary art, and to support its advancements, MOCA offers diverse experiences through exhibitions, collaborations, community events, publications, lectures and performances.

properties.name: Museum of Outdoor Arts
properties.description: Posted by Baobot  1000 Englewood Parkway, Englewood, CO, United StatesThe Museum of Outdoor Arts is dedicated to bringing the vitality of the arts into the everyday life of the people of Colorado. Being a museum without walls, MOA\'s collection of outdoor sculpture reaches out to both the casual passerby and the serious art critic. Public art is displayed against a background of superb architecture, sweeping landscapes, and attractive urban environments. The collection appeals to families, educators, students, and visitors alike. When art is integral to all we do, it is present in the classroom and the boardroom, in the soaring design of a bridge as well as a maze of city sidewalks. Art gladdens celebrations, informs inventions, and inspires collective creativity by expanding awareness of what is possible. We hope you enjoy this website and have the opportunity to experience our collection in person. Cynthia Madden Leitner President Museum of Outdoor Arts ---www.moaonline.org

properties.name: Ogden Theatre
properties.description: Posted by Baobot 935 E. Colfax Ave., Denver, CO, United StatesOpened in 1918, the Ogden Theatre was Denver??s leading vaudeville house before it transformed into a second-run movie theater, which it remained until closing in 1990. In 1993, Doug Kauffman of Nobody in Particular Presents re-opened the Ogden as a concert venue, forever fusing rock and roll with the theater??s storied history: In its eighty-eight year existence, the Ogden has hosted everyone from Harry Houdini to Iggy Pop, Jackson Brown to the Smashing Pumpkins. Now Nobody in Particular has revitalized the theater to ensure it thrives for another eight decades. Designed by NIPP??s Steve Schalk, a Hollywood prop master who spearheaded the renovation of the Gothic Theater in 1999, the new Ogden features state-of-the art architectural elements that both preserve the building??s historical integrity and reintroduce it as a world-class concert venue, designed with the audience in mind. An intimate wrap-around balcony, enlarged stage and improved sight lines increase capacity and ensure there??s not a bad seat in the house. The sound system was entirely rebuilt by sound engineer Bret Dowlen of Dowlen Sound; recycled materials that line the floors improve the acoustics, making this one of the best sounding rooms in town. The new Ogden is a treat for the senses, as well, with ornamental steel rails, a beautiful, hand-crafted bar on the upper-tier balcony and a whimsical, color-saturated interior by decorative painter Karin Mirick, owner of Denver??s Create a Scene. Even the bathrooms have been remodeled. The theater??s original proscenium remains intact, however, as do many of the design flourishes built by the original architects. As a feat of design and an investment in the revitalization of Colfax, the new Ogden is an instant clas

properties.name: Old Louisville Inn
properties.description: Posted by Baobot  740 Front St., Louisville, CO, United StatesWelcome to the O.L.I, the Old Louisville Inn. The beautiful antique back bar was built in the 1880s by the Brunswick Company Factory in Dubuque, Iowa. It is a cherry wood, birch, and mahogany âDel Monteâ model, was cut-to-fit and constructed with no nails. The Brunswick bar spent about ten years in Leadville, Colorado. At the turn of the century this building was built and owned by E.J. Difrancia, who was Louisvilleâs agent for Tivoli Beer in Denver. Tivoli worked with him to bring the back bar to Louisville. It remains one of Coloradoâs two oldest antique bars and is a priceless treasure in our community. Due to dangerous gases in the coal mines, miners could not smoke, so most used chewing tobacco. This is the reason for the copper spit trough (once equipped with running water) that still exists along the floor of the front bar.

properties.description: Posted by Baobot 4705 Montview Boulevard, Denver, CO, United StatesThe Enos Mills Group, or the local Denver Sierra Club Group is conducting a general membership meeting at the Denver Public Library Park Hill Branch location on Tuesday, February 13th from 6-8:00 p.m. Refreshments will be served and attendence is FREE. The meeting\'s theme is "The City as Park." Come hear about the Greenprint Denver initiative and how it relates to the City\'s park system. A representative from Denver Parks will talk with our group about their plan to plant 7000 trees in 7 days in April! Come to meet fellow Sierrans, make new friends and find out what\'s new with the parks program & what you can do to help enhance and expand the tree canopy. Park Hill Branch location is at the corner of Montview and Dexter. If you cannot make this meeting and wish to learn more about the Enos Mills Group, please contact Libby Tart-Schoenfelder at libbylaine@earthlink.net or 303-393-0217. All are welcome at our events!

properties.name: Parker Dance Academy, Parker, CO
properties.description: Posted by Baobot  Parker Rd. and Hilltop, Parker, CO, United StatesARE YOU INTERESTED IN BECOMING A MEMBER OF THE ST. LOUIS HOOFERâS CLUB/ COLORADO CHAPTER? 1) Do you run tap steps in your sleep? 2) Do you have a hard time getting OFF the stage? 3) Is âdiggity-digâ not something you do in your garden? Well, if you are a young tapper â 18 and under â The St. Louis Hooferâs Club might be a great way to dance with other kids who share your passion for the art while learning from a Master! Mr. Robert L. Reed founded the St. Louis Hooferâs Club, as well as The St. Louis Tap Festival and Tap Heritage, Inc. and will be coming to Colorado on a monthly basis to share his extensive knowledge of the artform. The St. Louis Hoofer Clubâs mission is to teach the dance to the next generation, so that they may pass it on. Mr. Reed brings the history of the dance, which was passed to him by his mentor, Maceo Anderson of the Four Step Brothers, to his teaching and will instill the importance of perpetuating the tradition of tap to the young hoofers. Through a balance of rhythm, history, shading, and musicality, Mr. Reed hopes to keep tap strong and thriving for future generations to enjoy. The St. Louis Hoofers have enjoyed experiences nationally, as well as internationally. They have been a great presence at Reedâs The St. Louis Tap Festival, now in its 15th year. Mr. Reed is instrumental in providing young dancers with the tools they need to reach their goals. SLHC classes will bring committed students together for an exceptional learning experience. These classes are especially valuable to the community because they introduce extraordinary perspectives from history. Mr. Reed is an exceptional educator who considers teaching an essential part of sharing and building the art form. He believes that once the children respect the dance, they will love it. Mr. Reed will be holding auditions for The Hoofers Club â CO Chapter Nov. 17th. Please contact Colorado Dance Coalition at info@ColoradoDanceCoalition.com or 303.482.1846 to reserve your audition spot today! Auditions will be 1.5 - 2 hours long and be in the form of a Master Class on November 17th from 4-6 p.m at Parker Dance Academy, Parker, CO. Audition fee is 0. Kids are welcome to take the class without auditioning and may be excused if Mr. Reed needs to see the auditioners separately during the last half hour. If accepted, first rehearsal will be Sunday Nov. 19 in the afternoon for 3 hours. Times TBA. Time commitment includes a 3-hour rehearsal once a month and a 1Â½ -hour Master Class once a month, with Mr. Reed, as well as a one-hour practice each week that Mr. Reed is not in CO for review. Hoofers Club fees include 5 registration fee, 30 dues per month (This includes Hoofers 3 hr. rehearsal and 1.5 hour master class,) and per week teacher fee for off-weeks. Participation in The St. Louis Tap Festival in St. Louis in July is mandatory. Thank you from COLORADO DANCE COALITION, P.O. BOX 4652, PARKER, CO 80134, www.ColoradoDanceCoalition.com

Cascade Avenue, Colorado Springs, CO, United StatesOur Mission The mission of the Pikes Peak Center is to serve as a quality entertainment, cultural, educational, and assembly center for the benefit of the citizens of El Paso County and the Pikes Peak Region. History Built by the citizens of El Paso County in 1982 to serve as a regional entertainment and cultural center, the Pikes Peak Center\'s downtown Colorado Springs location was planned as a part of the economic revitalization strategy for the downtown business district. Since its opening in 1982, the Pikes Peak Center has achieved international acclaim for its design and acoustical qualities. Artists and critics alike have been lavish in their praise of the Center. The Center hosts in excess of 200 performances annually. The Center is owned by El Paso County and operated by the Colordo Springs World Arena, a 501(c)(3) organization.

properties.name: Randolph's
properties.description: Posted by Baobot1776 Grant Street, Denver, CO, United StatesRandolph\'s Restaurant | The legendary William Randolph Hearst was a man of power and prestige, money and influence. He was a visionary in the realms of publishing, politics, architecture and classic American life in the early 1900s. In 1926, Hearst commissioned the historic Warwick Hotel New York for his paramour, Marion Davis, to host their famous friends and colleagues from Hollywood and the world of theatre. The original Warwick captures the elegance and grace of European style, and its tradition and cachet is evident in each of the Warwick Hotels that have opened around the world since 1926. In keeping with this tradition and building upon reputation, Randolph\'s Restaurant & Bar, named after Mr. Hearst, is located in the Warwick Denver Hotel. The restaurant serves contemporary American Cuisine and classic cocktails in a backdrop of comfortable elegance - reminiscent of the Warwick New York\'s speak-easy spirit in the late 1920s. Chef Dave Oliveri offers a menu that is artful yet unpretentious. The menu changes seasonally and is complemented by an award-winning wine. Randolph\'s houses three distinct spaces: the bar, the restaurant and the patio. Here, our patrons take pleasure in everything from wine tastings and wine dinners to happy hour, media networking events and business lunches. We offer something for everyone without compromising the stylish comfort that is Randolph\'s hallmark. | Randolph\'s Bar | Also a must-visit for diversified and memorable cocktails. Named one of "Denver\'s Best Happy Hours" by 5280 Magazine, Randolph\'s bar is the perfect place to relax and end a long day with friends. Enjoy some classic cocktails in the shade of our terraced patio or on cooler nights enjoy the warm atmosphere at the bar. Original, vibrant, trendy, are just a few words that describe this stylish outlet. | Randolph\'s Patio | If the temperatures of spring, summer or fall are invited, enjoy the terraced patio, which provides not only alfresco happy hour, but also perfect views of the Colorado sunset reflected off the buildings of downtown Denver. properties.name: Red Lion Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Baobot 1975 Bryant Street, Denver, CO, United StatesExtreme Data: Rethinking the "I" in IT It is remarkable how far we have come with digital information. Sensors can report the realtime status of an engine in the bowels of a ship so that costly emergency shut-downs can be avoided. Data from your car can report your actual driving behavior and (hopefully) lower your insurance rates. From your home PC you can access air quality and other EPA ratings for your town, or take an aerial "fly over" of your neighborhood or just about anywhere in the world. Location-based cell phone blogging is taking hold. You can even use your cell phone to check in for an airplane flight or, in the future, to take the place of a train ticket. An information explosion is underway, giving rise to an era of extreme data and dramatic new applications. Extreme data is new types of data, generated by new devices, and being used in new ways - enabling new business processes, interpersonal connections, and knowledge for organizations and individuals. This session will explore four areas of extreme data: data everywhere, time and place, social connections and meaning. Paul Gustafson is an accomplished technologist and proven leader in emerging technologies, applied research and strategy. As director of the LEF Technology Programs, Paul brings vision and leadership to a portfolio of programs and directs the technology research agenda. Astute at recognizing technology trends, how they inter-relate, and their implications for business, Paul brings his insights to bear on client strategy, CSC research, leadership development and innovation strategy. He has published numerous papers and articles on strategic technology issues and speaks to executive audiences frequently on these top

properties.name: Red Rocks Amphitheatre
properties.description: Posted by BaobotRed Rocks Park, Morrison, CO, United StatesNestled in the Rocky Mountain Foothills fifteen miles west of Denver, there stands a symbol of nature\'s unparalleled majesty. Red Rocks is a geologically formed, open-air Amphitheatre that is not duplicated anywhere in the world. With Mother Nature as the architect, the design of the Amphitheatre consists of two, three hundred-foot monoliths (Ship Rock and Creation Rock) that provide acoustic perfection for any performance. The area of Red Rocks, originally known as the Garden of Angels, has attracted the attention of musical performers since before the turn of the century. The majestic setting of the Amphitheatre, along with the panoramic view of Denver, makes for a breathtaking scene. ---www.redrocksonline.com

properties.name: Reed Photo-Art Gallery
properties.description: Posted by Baobot 833 Santa Fe Dr, Denver, CO, United States"BEAUTY OF THE BEAST â TIGERS FACING EXTINCTION" Traveling Art Exhibtion by Renowned Wildlife Artist, Francesca Owens Using brilliant colors â characteristic of her signature style â combined now with sobering graphic black and white images with hints of orange red charcoals, a poignant expression suggestive of this animal\'s fate, Owens creates a dynamic tension between art and reality. The âBeauty of The Beast - Tigers Facing Extinctionâ traveling art exhibition will begin its tour visiting Reed Photo Art Gallery, beginning March 17th - May 16, 2007. In late 2005, Francesca created a series of 9 mixed medium â titled "Did I Die in Vain" and in 2007 she completed the last three of, "Am I Really Gone?" - all various charcoal, graphite and print relief works of art that portrayed the key elements tigers are facing as they approach extinction in the wild. International attention ignited after Brian Gratwicke, assistant director for the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation - Save the Tiger Fund (STT) publicized these images on their website, which immediately linked Owens with wildlife biologists from around the world. âThe series is sobering, and emotionally exhausting but ends with a message of hope...by an extraordinary picture of this spirited animal literally exploding from the back of a Land Rover and aptly titled âReleaseâ." an STT spokesperson reflects. âBeauty of The Beast - Tigers Facing Extinctionâ traveling art exhibition will begin its tour visiting universities across the United States in 2

properties.name: Reinke Brothers
properties.description: Posted by Baobot5663 S. Prince St., Littleton, CO, United StatesBack in 1968 Greg and Chris Reinke started exploring the "Haunted Attraction" business at the local fishing hole. Their father didn\'t like fishing so the boys were on their own. After a full day of floating worms Greg and Chris began their glorious career by hooking their first business asset, a shopping cart. After a rigorous cleaning of their new equipment the boys set up shop, in the basement of their parent\'s home. Borrowing a plaster skull from their older brother Don, and their father\'s footlocker for a coffin they began to construct the walls, blankets hung from the rafters of their new empire. Halloween was fast approaching and they were anticipating a great season. Soon their first customers approached. Ding-dong the doorbell rung and the first of their twenty-six clients of the evening were paying their penny and descending the stairs to the basement. "Climb in and be prepared to be scared" Greg would exclaim. Pushing the cart through the maze of blankets, props and scenes Greg would pull strings to cause movement in each room to terrorize their clients. Strings were cutting edge of animatronics at the time. As Chris fed the extension cord, which ran the electrical grid for the "Mansion of Terror", providing power to the strobe light mounted on the front of the cart (It was a good effect). Soon the woman who vaulted the brothers into the limelight came to the door. Not being able to climb into the cart she began her walking experience and with amazement she asked, "What would you charge to build this Haunted House for Saint Mary\'s Carnival?" Greg thought quickly and said "Fifty dollars." The boy\'s career had begun! The moral of the story is, teach your kids to f

properties.name: Saint John's Cathedral
properties.description: Posted by Baobot1350 Washington, Denver, CO, United StatesBefore Colorado became a state or even a territory, before the City of Denver was incorporated, our congregation was founded during the Colorado gold rush as the Church of Saint John in the Wilderness. Today Saint John\'s remains a vibrant congregation rooted in our history and continues its tradition of living on the frontier. We are the Cathedral Church of the Episcopal Diocese of Colorado. As a Cathedral, Saint John\'s is the seat of the Bishop of Colorado. The Cathedral is also a church for the City of Denver, a home for Episcopalians throughout the state, a leading congregation of the Episcopal Church and an active participant in the worldwide Anglican Communion. Our mission is "to know Christ and to make Christ known." We live this mission by welcoming and including all. We are a community of communities, a large congregation with a place for everyone. We strive to include children and youth in all aspects of our life. We care for one another and also reach out to others who are in need. We are a house of prayer for all people. We are a place for questions and rediscovery, for stillness and growth. ---www.sjcathedral.org

properties.name: Sandy Carson Gallery
properties.description: Posted by Baobot 760 Santa Fe Dr., Denver, CO, United StatesEstablished in 1975, the gallery has always been located in areas adjacent to downtown. Our present home is within two miles of the Denver Art Museum, the Performing Arts Center, and the 16th and 17th street shopping and business locales. Four years after our purchase of this building on Santa Fe Drive, the area has developed into a vibrant, thriving arts district with over a dozen galleries, a museum and a theater. In a Denver Post newspaper article the neighborhood was titled ??The Heart of Art." The community has given it that identity as well; hundreds of art viewers visit the Santa Fe Art District first Fridays of each month. If there is a symbolic and spiritual reality, then various circumstances confirmed the appropriateness of the purchase of our building at 760 Santa Fe Drive. It was meant to be. In 1999, I discovered when reading the deed papers of our 1889 building, that it was once owned by Vance Kirkland, one of Denver??s internationally recognized painters. Further confirmation that we had bought the right place came when our contractor found a candle in the shape of an angel in the basement of the building and asked if I wanted to keep it. Having just lost our beloved daughter, Jodi, the angel, to me, represented her presence in the art world that so captivated her. The angel sits on my desk as a perpetual reminder of how fitting this building is as the gallery??s home. Having 4800 square feet, the gallery is divided into a 2700 square foot exhibition space with moveable walls which create an ever changing backdrop for our shows. The back room is always open for perusal and contains a presentation area and hundreds of artworks: canvases, drawings, limited edition prints, sculptures, tapestries, photographs, furniture- a veritable banquet of art resources. Not only is our gallery a forum for our artists, but we have exhibited their work in art fairs in Chicago, New York, Miami and Seattle. In this way, the artists we so admire are exposed to a national audience. Although we represent many established artists of significant reputation, we take great pleasure in the career development of talented, emerging young artists. We have never limited our search for the stimulating and the innovative in art. Therefore, we have not restricted our stable of artists, which continues to grow. From the inception of the business, The Carson Group, Art Consultants has been a parallel arm to our gallery. As an advisory service, for our clients, it provides yet another means for collectors to acquire art and to explore the plethora of works in the art world. We streamline the process for them and reduce the overwhelming amount of information to a graspable selection of appropriate material. It is our purpose to provide art that is timeless in its visual statement. Art that piques the intellect as well as the emotions never loses its appeal. Uncrating or unwrapping the artwork for our next exhibit is like opening presents, a constant delight. Despite the numerous exhibits over the years, I am always energized when I see the new artwork. In an atmosphere of cordiality and informality, we are pleased to discuss and present the art that inhabits our building. ---www.sandycarsongallery.com

properties.name: Swallow  Hill Music Hall
properties.description: Posted by Baobot 71 E. Yale Ave., Denver, COAsk anyone at Swallow Hill, and you will get a different answer. Defining Swallow Hill Music Association is almost as difficult as defining what folk music is! How would YOU describe it? Is is "Denver\'s home for folk, roots and acoustic music"? A non-profit, 501c(3) organization dedicated to the preservation and presentation of folk music in the Rocky Mountain region? The oldest multicultural folk arts organization in the region? The only place of its kind between Freight & Salvage in Berkeley and the Old Town School in Chicago? Like the story of the blind men and the elephant, each of us sees Swallow Hill from our own perspective. For some of us, Swallow Hill is a music school. We revel in the extensive selection of classes, jam sessions, clubs and incredible workshops with touring artists. Others celebrate it as a concert venue, where performers from all over the world come to play and sing, offering Denver a breadth and depth of talent that it would not have witnessed otherwise. For others, Swallow Hill is a coffee house, a cozy place where we can get together for an open stage or hear a great new songwriter. Many musicians know Swallow Hill as the home of the Sawtelle Recording Studio, while many in the arts community see us as a "living museum," the protector of the folk spirit and legacy. Still others see Swallow Hill as a place to volunteer, to find camaraderie in working together to make a difference in the community. Swallow Hill is also a veritable grab-bag of sounds and styles: bluegrass, Celtic, cowboy swing, gospel spirituals, African-American rural blues, Jewish Klezmer, traditional Spanish, Cajun & Zydeco, shape-note singing, to name but a few. And let\'s not forget the other folk arts of dancing (Appalachian clogging, Ceili, contra dance...), storytelling, songwriting, and even music business basics (an arcane art to many). Swallow Hill\'s accomplishments over the years are staggering. What began with a small group of volunteers has grown into one of the largest arts organizations in the region. Swallow Hill has won both the Mayor\'s and Governor\'s Awards for Excellence in the Arts, has been recognized by the North American Folk Alliance, has won countless Westword "Best of Denver" awards, has achieved SCFD Tier II status, and is one of the most sought-after venues by folk/roots artists in the country. But beyond the programs that Swallow Hill presents, beyond the lists of artists, teachers, instruments, styles and accomplishments, Swallow Hill is a community of people drawn together by a common love of music. This is the place where we connect with our "musical family." ---www.swallowhill.com

properties.name: Theatre On Broadway
properties.description: Posted by Baobot 13 S. Broadway, Denver, CO, United StatesTheatre Group began over 30 years ago as a community theatre program known as the Lakewood Players. With a strong base of community contributions from the theatre artists around Denver, Lakewood Players rapidly emerged as one of the stronger nonprofit community theatres in the state. In the mid??eighties, Lakewood Players later changed locations and underwent a name change, now known as Theatre On Broadway at 13 South Broadway. At their new venue, Theatre Group made great strides forward in business and artistic value, and in our second season were securing the rights to Broadway and Off??Broadway plays premiering in Colorado. Subsequently, Theatre Group was awarded several Denver Drama Critics Circle Awards and received the highly coveted Best Season. Not only did Theatre Group become synonymous with artistic excellence(David Marlowe, OutFront Colorado Magazine) with the theatre??going public as a whole, but they also capture a large share of the Gay and Lesbian community as well. By 1996 TOB had become the preeminent gay theatre in the state with the acclaimed premiers of Jeffrey, Six Degrees of Separation, Howard Crabtree??s Whoop Dee Doo!, Poor Super Man, Love! Valour! Compassion!, and Corpus Christi. Theatre On Broadway has become successful, in great part, by addressing the entertainment and theatrical needs of a very loyal homosexual marketplace ???? audiences who crave quality gay??themed shows that would not otherwise be found outside New York, Chicago, or Los Angeles. ---www.theatregroup.org

properties.name: US Thai Cafe

properties.name: Virgilio's Pizzeria Napoletana
properties.description: Posted by Baobot7986 W. Alameda Ave., Lakewood, CO, United StatesItalians have always had a love affair with food. They show it with its abundance, subtle flavors, freshness, simplicity, and consistency. Only a true Italian could convey these tastes and emotions to others. Only at Virgilio\'s Pizzeria Napoletana could you experience all this as "un membro della nostra famiglia" -- a member of our family. Virgilio was born on the outskirts of Naples, Italy. He came to the United States in 1966 with his parents and brother, settling in New Haven County, Connecticut, 60 miles outside of New York City. Though âLâAmericaâ was their new home, the family took the best of Italy with them: the magical cuisine of their homeland. Virgilio learned to cook from his mother, who treated every meal as an event. Cupboards were filled only with jars of vegetables, fruits and fresh herbs which were grown by the family. Breads never came in a plastic bag, only from âmamaâsâ oven. And each day, the sweet scent of garlic, parsley and sweet basil heating in olive oil filled the air as another fresh pot of tomato sauce was slowly simmering to perfection. In addition to the world class ingredients used in making our pizza, the way in which it is cooked is purely Italian. Brick ovens were first discovered among the ruins of ancient Pompeii. The brick oven evokes a time when life was slower, and the food was simply better. It allows us to enjoy a style of cooking that is both authentic and enjoyable, and delivers unmatched results, which is why each and every pizza at Virgilio\'s Pizzeria Napoletana is cooked in this age old manner. To this very day, his family still grows their own tomatoes in their backyard garden, making every pot of tomato sauce from scratch! There is simply no compromise when it comes to the quality of food on their table. Just as Virgilioâs family carried that tradition from Italy to the United States, Virgilio now carries this timeless family tradition of freshness and uncompromising quality of the food served to our guests here at Virgilioâs Pizzeria Napoletana. Mangia
